2‚É£ w3c verifiable credentials (powered by @auth0)

‚Üí a verifiable credential of w3c standard are digital and cryptographically verifiable credentials which can be stored on digital devices and can utilize cryptography to verify their data and authorship

Recent years have seen strides in the challenging realm of user control, thanks to breakthroughs in decentralized identity, championed by the W3C initiative on Verifiable Credentials and Decentralized Identifiers.

"Verifiable Credentials which are anchored on the CORD blockchain are developed around a specification from the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C)," says @Dhiwaynetworks Founder Satish Mohan

https://t.co/mP7ybToibc

If Twitter really collapses I will miss community notes the most because unfortunately neither Mastodon nor Bluesky has currently a similar feature though I guess it might be possible to implement something similar with Bluesky's/ATProtocol's planned user-driven moderation-tools.

@gordonbrander Only things that maybe doable and achievable are:
- Censorship resistant permissionless DNS-ish #pkarr
- Censorship resistant permissionless S3-ish (maybe something similar or simpler than AtProtocol PDS)

Interoperablity that requires consent and work are doomed.
@jack what are your thoughts on ActivityPub vs the ATProtocol? I don't understand why there are two different ones and why their differences matter :/
